questions.query: How does your project contribute to the growth of the OSS ecosystem? Please provide specific examples of how your application enhances or expands the current ecosystem.
questions.explanation:
### 1) Promoting other open-source projects

ReFi is full of open-source projects trying to facilitate funding for grassroots ecological and social impact. We are keenly aware that open-source software stands a much better chance of impacting people's lives on the ground than its closed-source counterpart. For one, open-source allows for horizontal scale. Other localities can fork the software and tailor for their own needs without having to worry about having too little profit potential for closed-source alternatives.

As such, we shed light on the impact these open-source projects are making. Regen Network, Open Forest Protocol, GoodDollar, Glo Dollar, and M3tering Protocol, to name some examples. 

### 2) Educating ReFi/regen projects on how to use open-source tools

Although the educational series is not yet launched, we are firmly committed to helping builders maximise the use of open-source tools in their solutions. Given funding constraints and the unique needs of ReFi projects, open-source tools are the only viable option. But this means significant work needs to surface the right tools and help builders to leverage them. Our partnership with GreenPill Writers Guild is designed to do just that as part of the larger Local ReFi Toolkit driven by Regen Coordination.

### 3) A blueprint for an ecosystem information hub

CARBON Copy can be easily forked by any project that wants to start mapping/covering an ecosystem. We think this is a great way to shed light on niche ecosystems. DeSci, for example, would benefit from such a hub.

The next major part of this is adding a way to decentralize management of the hub so that it can be community run. We've already put together the [first draft](https://github.com/carboncopyrefi/carbon-copy-site/wiki/Ecosystem-Management-Tool-Specs) of the specs for your perusal.

### 4) Open data

Access to our ReFi data API is available upon request. We are working to make it publicly available this year.

questions.query: What features or use cases does your dApp/App present? How is it differentiated?
questions.explanation:
### 1) Curated ReFi Project database

A curated list of all projects in and tangential to the ReFi space. Each project has its own profile page, while each category also has its own dedicated page.

The database also manifests as a landscape diagram that maps out the space into various categories.

### 2) ReFi Impact Dashboard

One of the biggest challenges for ReFi projects is demonstrating impact. This is partly because projects are small and don't, by themselves, represent significant impact. But it's also due to not having an aggregator like DeFi Llama or Growthepie.xyz.

We've set out to fill this void by designing a simple dashboard that displays aggregated impact data across key impact metrics. It's currently in early beta, but we hope to improve it 

### 3) Other ReFi ecosystem data

We also track builders, opportunities, knowledge, news, media coverage, fundraising, and tokens to provide a well-rounded view of the space.

### 4) Education

Much of our content is designed to educate readers about ReFi and the work being done in the space. 

We've also developed a [Web3 fundraising guide](https://carboncopy.news/guides/web3-grant-fundraising-guide-ngo/) specifically for Nigeria that has since served as the foundation for The ReFi Club - a 150-strong community of aspiring regens in the country.

We are looking to expand our educational offering through a partnership with GreenPill Writers Guild (more details in the next question).

### Differentiation

We are the only comprehensive information source for the ReFi space. In other words, a combination of CoinDesk, Crunchbase, and DeFi Llama but for Web3-powered ecological and social impact.

We're also the only project looking to aggregate the impact being made by the entire ecosystem as a means to build its stature in the eyes of the larger Web3 industry and climate/development finance.

questions.query: What are your plans for further development, and how will the grant funds be used to achieve these goals?
questions.explanation:
### 1) Integrate impact data from more projects 

We've currently integrated just over 20 projects but would like to integrate 20-30 more to make our aggregate metrics more indicative of the work being done in the space.

The primary benefit of integrating data from more projects is that our dashboard becomes more comprehensive.

### 2) Launch v1 of the ReFi Impact Dashboard

Aside from integrating more data, the dashboard needs more interactivity. Users need to be able to drill down into metrics to see project-specific data, changes over time, and sub-categorization (e.g., ecological credit types).

In addition, we also want to capture data from new impact reporting frameworks. As Regen Coordination's efforts to integrate its CIDS impact reporting framework into Karma GAP begin to bear fruit, it's important that we include this data in our dashboard.

### 3) Publish educational content series by GreenPill Writers Guild

A series of research-based articles to explore a key question: how much are ReFi communities using Web3 tools, and how are those tools affecting their work?

When tech is difficult to use or has a steep learning curve, projects default to using tools they are familiar with. Despite the promise of using Web3 tools for decentralization, many ReFi projects still rely on familiar, centralized tools like Google Sheets and common messaging apps. By identifying pain points and surfacing real-world experiences, we can support better tooling decisions.

Deliverables:

- A long-form educational report featuring case studies, real-world use cases, an overview of the pros and cons of commonly used Web3 tools, and actionable recommendations linked to the Local ReFi Toolkit.

- A set of survey tools and datasets for reuse in future work

- Summaries and explainer pieces for social media distribution

### 4) Continue work on ecosystem management tool

As per our stated milestone on [Karma GAP](https://gap.karmahq.xyz/project/carbon-copy-1/funding/0xbf279cdb15ce4eb6397ae7ac3011592a86a1f95e08e4e157287299ed81a0f45a/milestones-and-updates) after the GG22 dApps and Apps round, we have completed the [first draft](https://github.com/carboncopyrefi/carbon-copy-site/wiki/Ecosystem-Management-Tool-Specs) of the specs for the additions we need to make to CARBON Copy. The next step is to hire a smart contract developer that can develop the necessary smart contracts.

## How will the funds be used?

### 1) Hire a developer

We're hoping to raise enough to cover the cost of the smart contract work and, provided we find a developer who also has JS and Python experience, integration/dashboard work.

### 2) Support the writing, research, coordination, and content design of the educational series

Please include a separate line for each unique deployer address and blockchain combination.
questions.explanation: N/A - haven't yet begun the process of writing the smart contracts.

data.title: Publish content by Greenpill Writers Guild
data.description: A major part of our grant application was centred around a partnership with Greenpill Writers Guild. The aim is for GPWG to produce educational content to support ReFi builders. This includes things like Web3 tooling guides.

data.title: Deploy next version of ReFi Impact Dashboard
data.description:
After publishing the early beta of the dashboard, we set out to better understand the data, metrics, and features that would make the dashboard truly valuable to stakeholders.

With the funds raised from this round, we are able to hire a freelance developer to build the next version of the dashboard as a standalone project. This includes a new data structure, API, and front-end.

What it does not include is integrating impact data from more projects. We are laying the groundwork with this release in order to make future integration easier.

data.name: Gitcoin
data.description: Gitcoin creates solutions that empower digitally native communities to fund, build, and protect what matters.

questions.explanation: kent@carboncopy.news

questions.query: Team Size
Is your project a member or past grantee of one of these networks?
questions.explanation: Not formally

questions.query: What are your key active goals, plans, objectives or milestones for this year?
questions.explanation:
- Hire a developer to integrate impact data from more projects and expand the ReFi Impact Dashboard in coordination with Regen Coordination

- Publish educational content series in partnership with GreenPill Writers Guild and support Local ReFi Toolkit Playbooks efforts

- Publish 2025 editions of the State of ReFi and Impact DePIN reports

- Publish quarterly ReFi progress reports

- Expand geographic breadth of content to cover 5 key ReFi hotspots: Latin America, West Africa, East Africa, South Asia, Southeast Asia.

- Launch ergodic ecosystem investing pilot for ReFi

- Continue building open-source ecosystem management tool

- Solicit more guest feature contributions from ReFi/regen thinkers

data.name: Regen Coordination
data.description: The Regen Coordination Round is a proposal for a GG21 community round centered on the themes of Coordi-nations 3, Cosmo-localism 2, Bio-Regionalism 3, and Regenerative Finance (ReFi) 3. Bringing together GreenPill Network 1, ReFi DAO 1, Celo Regional DAOs 1 and Regens Unite 1, we aim to support a global movement of regenerative communities leveraging Web3 for real-world impact and addressing local needs. The round will feed into a program to support the further development of local community impact tracking methodologies, grant tooling interoperability, and integrated QF & RPGF. We have currently secured $60K in funding from Celo Public Goods, ReFi DAO and Greenpill and ask for Gitcoin’s backing as we embark on a shared mission to showcase how community coordination, Web3, and innovative financial mechanisms can enable ecological and social regeneration on a global scale.

questions.explanation: To expand the geographic scope of our content. We currently focus mostly on Africa, but would like to expand to Latin America and South/Southeast Asia. We will use the funds to pay freelance writers in those regions for articles. Aiming for 2, possibly 3 articles.

questions.query: What is the timeframe for the work funded?

data.title: Source 2-3 articles from freelance writers in Latin America and South/Southeast Asia

data.reason:
We focused our attention on Latin America given the predominance of ReFi projects active in the region.

Both articles were written by Tereza Bizkova of ReFi Medellin and ReFi Podcast:

[Unlocking Blockchain Solutions to Protect Latin America's Biodiversity](https://carboncopy.news/features/unlocking-blockchain-solutions-protect-latin-america-latam-biodiversity/)

[The One Thing Holding ReFi Back in Latin America](https://carboncopy.news/features/one-thing-holding-refi-back-latin-america/)

We focused our attention on Latin America given the predominance of ReFi projects active in the region.

Both articles were written by Tereza Bizkova of ReFi Medellin and ReFi Podcast:

[Unlocking Blockchain Solutions to Protect Latin America's Biodiversity](https://carboncopy.news/features/unlocking-blockchain-solutions-protect-latin-america-latam-biodiversity/)

[The One Thing Holding ReFi Back in Latin America](https://carboncopy.news/features/one-thing-holding-refi-back-latin-america/)

data.name: Giveth
data.description: Zero-fee crypto donation platform that rewards donors to verified public goods projects. Donate to a verified project & get rewarded.

data.title: Integrate impact metrics for 20 projects
data.description:
This is the first step towards building our ReFi impact dashboard. Each project will have its metrics displayed on its profile page.

***Note**: We fell short of our original goal of 50 projects, so we modified the milestone to reflect what we we were able to accomplish.

The ReFi impact dashboard aims to provide a snapshot of the impact being made in the ReFi space at any given moment. The beta version will display a small number of metrics with the goal of getting feedback from the community.
data.title: Release ReFi Impact Dashboard beta

data.reason: We have launched the early beta of our ReFi Impact Dashboard with data from 20 projects and 12 metrics, plus a feed of Karma GAP impacts from the last 90 days.
We have launched the early beta of our ReFi Impact Dashboard with data from 20 projects and 12 metrics, plus a feed of Karma GAP impacts from the last 90 days.

data.text:
We are well behind on the delivery of v1 of the ReFi Impact Dashboard. This is in large part due to data limitations, shifting priorities, and the absence of a dedicated developer.

More generally, we underestimated the amount of work involved to integrate data from 50 projects and deliver an interactive dashboard.

Our current plan is to allocate funding from subsequent grant rounds to the hiring of a developer that can help us deliver on our initial promises.
data.title: Dashboard and Data Integration Q1 2025 Update

data.text:
We've only been able to integrate impact data for 17 projects to date. It hasn't been nearly as straightforward as we hoped it would be. Few projects have explicitly open data sources, Dune dashboards, or Subgraph queries.

We find it unfortunate that data transparency isn't more of a priority. Our sense is that projects take it for granted that blockchain is transparent without really understanding what that means in practice.

The output link is one example of data integration.
data.title: Data integration update

data.text: We released the early beta of the ReFi Impact Dashboard and integrated impact data from 22 projects.

questions.query: Project GitHub Repo
questions.explanation: https://github.com/carboncopyrefi/carbon-copy-site, https://github.com/carboncopyrefi/carbon-copy-api

questions.query: Have you participated in a previous Gitcoin Grants Round? If so, please name the rounds or link the builder profile associated with previous rounds.
questions.explanation: GG20 $EARTH, GG21 Climate Solutions and Asia

questions.query: How does your project contribute to the growth of the OSS ecosystem? Please provide specific examples of how your application enhances or expands the current ecosystem.
questions.explanation:
Two ways:

1) Providing an open Web3 ecological and social impact dataset

As it stands now, there is no aggregated data source of the ecological and social impact being made by Web3 projects. Most of the data is simply not available. The data that is publicly available is scattered across disparate sources, both on-chain and off-chain. My building this dataset, we believe projects will be more likely to open up their own data sources.

2) Building an open-source, NFT-gated ecosystem management tool

As described further down, it will start as a way for projects to own their profile pages, but we believe this feature will become a tool for ecosystem management. Someone in the DeSci ecosystem, for example, could leverage the tool to map the space and build a rich knowledge graph for stakeholders.

questions.query: What features or use cases does your dApp/App present? How is it differentiated?
questions.explanation:
1) Curated ReFi project database

Aside from our content work, we're mapping the entire ReFi space into a single database of projects, people, tokens, and impact. Each project has a dedicated profile page with associated data, such as fundraising, Karma GAP activity, blog content, news, media coverage, and impact metrics. Each category in our taxonomy also has its own profile page with aggregated data for the projects within it.

2) ReFi API

All of our data is available via our API upon request. We have yet to officially announce the API as public, but it's something we plan to do.

Endpoints include: ReFi project listing, project profile, token list, people listing, category profile, ReFi news feed, landscape (categories + projects), and Web3 ecological and social impact data.

questions.query: What are your plans for further development, and how will the grant funds be used to achieve these goals?
questions.explanation:
The next phase is split into two parts:

1) A ReFi impact dashboard 

We're nearing the early beta launch of our attempt to visualize ReFi's impact through the aggregation of project metrics. Things like on-chain ecological credits issued and UBI distributed.

The idea is to give ReFi projects a data foundation to stand on when pitching to investors or engaging  stakeholders. The data streams will be 100% open, so anyone can use them in their own projects.

There is still a long way to go, however. It's not as simple as tracking on-chain data and visualizing it. We expect it to take up to 6 months create a dashboard that is comprehensive enough to represent the entire ReFi space.


2) NFT-based project profile ownership

The other thing we want to do is cede control of the ReFi project database to the community. It's becoming too difficult for our team to keep it up to date.

Our thinking is to issue NFTs representing ownership in project profile pages. For a modest amount, most of which would go directly to a community fund, a project could own its profile page and the edit rights that come with it. They could edit the content themselves or delegate to someone else (perhaps through a bounty).

The community fund would be used to pay people to keep certain types of data updated - fundraising data, for example - and do general upkeep.


The grant funds would go a long way to helping us making CARBON Copy more community-centric. We'd use the money mostly to complete #2. We don't have smart contract developers on the team, so we'd need to pay one to complete the necessary work.

data.title: Detailed specs for ecosystem management tool
data.description: As we didn't raise enough to build the tool, our focus will be on finishing the specs so that it is ready to build once we get funding.

data.reason: We've put together specs for our ecosystem management tool that identify what needs to be developed. We now have a clearer idea of the resources required to get it developed.
We've put together specs for our ecosystem management tool that identify what needs to be developed. We now have a clearer idea of the resources required to get it developed.

data.text: We raised enough to produce detailed specs for our ecosystem management tool. While the doc remains a work in progress, we feel we have a good enough first draft to start the process if we are able to raise the funds in the next dApps and Apps round.

data.name: Gitcoin
data.description: Gitcoin creates solutions that empower digitally native communities to fund, build, and protect what matters.
